row.Text: What kind of LCD monitor?
Why is this CW?
I would add "...any *handset-agnostic* online services..." to your question title or you're going to get a ton of platform-specific answers.
Rhymes with Lucked Cape
so other people can add to the 'abilities' list. e.g. 'power on or off my dogs electric fence'.
Wireless security cam looks like the way I want to go, thanks!
Low tech solution (but higher tech than @Jherico's): could you cover it with something translucent and red to filter out most of the blue?
This is not about gadgets, it is about specific software. I don't think it belongs. Thoughts?
Trying a resistor was my instinct, but I wanted to get other opinions. By the way, although it makes no difference because the principles are the same, I said "blue" rather than "green".

@Niall: **Brilliant!** I will try that as soon as I can. Please post your suggestion as an answer. And I mentioned "duct tape" in my question (I would actually use electrical tape for the sake of appearance, but duct tape is more amusing).
I only found out about standby mode a few weeks ago, but it's great. Completely kills the keypad and has eliminated accidental number dialing.
I'm looking for a head unit, not a headset.
Community wiki please

**Genius!** I couldn't find my 3D glasses so I tried my [Cokin 003 red filter](http://www.cokin.com/filtres.html?=#003) which worked too well. I could see the red very well, but the blue was very dim. Renewed 3D search. Failed. Tried a red gel from my Halloween strobe light. Not strong enough. Now I'm discouraged about the red film I was thinking about buying at the hobby shop. However, I'm encouraged by the potential of this line of investigation. Also, the lens over the LED is blue. Facepalm! It's filtering out the red and possibly enhancing the blue! Thanks a million!

+1 I'm going to see where [Niall's suggestion](http://gadgets.stackexchange.com/questions/141/how-can-i-reduce-the-brightness-of-the-power-on-led-on-an-external-hd-enclosure/166#166) takes me, but I may use a resistor if I'm not satisfied with the results.
Thats good to know.
This belongs on WebApps: http://webapps.stackexchange.com/
There a some pretty decent VNC clients for iPhone. Some limited trial versions are free.
Get a task killer and TCP monitoring app. I had them for Windows Mobile and they were VERY helpful in working with the devices.
I gave up on a Bluetooth headest (Jabra 2820) because I could not listen to any MP3's or iheartradio over the Bluetooth, just make calls. Useful, but my wired headset is more fun.
D'oh! My bad. I should know that...I was a software test engineer for Harman AND I bought my wife the Sony mex-bt2700. Sorry bout that, not paying attention.
I will have to test this.
Wow. I remember wanting one of those over 10 years ago.
Also, GoodReader for iPad does a great job with PDFs
Deluge has an awesome web interface, is that not good enough? I use it on my iPhone.
Longer than a smartphone's battery will last you
I can second that they can last you way longer than you should actually care about it. When you transfer phones, just request a new one if you feel like it
@pinko good point, thanks
I did have the same thought, but concluded that they are both mainly used from smartphones. Happy to move it if the consensus is otherwise.

Full colour is not an issue for me, since most educational books and notes are photocopier-friendly
The biggest reason against iPad for me is it's tranmissive screen and feature creep, i don't want a "almost-computer", just a reading device.
Humorously enough the kindle with the latest updates can fit the "almost-computer" category and what made me discard it is it's price plus the taxes (i'm from spain, so taxes are applied, we're in a global world with region locking and protective meassures)

Maybe i should edit the question, since one of my motivations for ePub is because the mainstream editors in Spain chose Libranda http://www.libranda.com/ which forces you to use an Adobe Digital Editions compatible reader since in their press release said with so much idiocy that they will start conversations with Apple/Amazon/B&N in a second phase (read: when hell freezes over and you see polar bears there)

Locale for Android can do this kind of stuff, you can set it to switch stuff on or off, or run apps on your phone when certain conditions like fine/coarse location, time of day, etc are met. http://www.twofortyfouram.com/

And now alas they appear to be discontinued. It is a great watch, and the ability to update it with new software is quite nice. Battery life is great, 2 years or so, for the last three batteries. (Though I am on my second watch now, finally broke the stem after 5 someodd years).
Please let everyone include some more information, such as what does it do and why you use it so much. And perhaps even a screenshot, so it's easier to recognize different apps or what they do
That sounds like it could be perfect! Anything like this for iPhone?

Ottawa public library is now allowing to borrow eBook in secure ePub format (I assume Adobe DRM) which are compatible with the Kobo. I saw the reader device (eInk based, small, light, pretty neat) - $149 - and it was good reading experience. I am going to test if Kobo application on iPad cad process the ePub - but I am still tempted because regardless how great is iPad it is not good in bright light, sun and generally outdoor where there is lots of reflection sources.

Thanks, I'm aware of the contact lookup. It's interesting that (apparently) no one thought of duplicating a useful feature from the POTS system and driving its adoption. You'd think this could be an up-sell revenue opportunity. A couple bucks a month add-on.
I don't think this question belongs on this site. See our working definition of "electronic gadget" at http://meta.gadgets.stackexchange.com/questions/15/what-exactly-is-a-gadget.

I think the question is broader than just the Desire, but I'll add smartphone as they are the most power consuming devices.
Same here, mine is at least 7 years old and has never given me any trouble.
That looks really cool! Powering a laptop, wow! Doesn't look like I can easily get it and use it in Europe though. I hope there's something like it available over here.

Useful for someone who just doesn't want a camera in their phone, but probably not useful for someone trying to comply with a corporate security policy.

Thanks. I just think it's bizarre and maddening that these high-end $2000 TVs still have no better way to connect to a theater control system other than having a little infrared emitter that you tape in front of the IR eye.
The employer will see the lens and assume the camera is still there. Duct tape, spray paint and sandpaper are also options I wouldn't use.

I've gotten in the habit of using my phone or laptop. I have a *very* old Casio battery-only analog that fades in that I use at home.

Interesting question, but on further reflection it doesn't seem like a gadget question, but instead a computer networking question. This is probably better asked on Super User.
Its one of those a little here, a little there questions...

I just bought a Buffalo WZR-HP-G300NH for home use and am mostly happy with it. Though most of my issues seem to have been squirrel damage to the cable line into the house. I initially was blaming the router, till I saw the Cable modem reboot itself regularly.

It looks good, but I'm kinda wary about buying an expensive gadget with no customer support. Is there anything that's an active product?

Now it's called "Twitter for iPhone."

I played around with the cables and hooked the cable box up via component cables instead of HDMI. This fixed the issue, so I'm thinking that the TV's "autodetect" of HDMI devices is causing something like this to happen.
I'd still prefer to use HDMI though (less cable tangling and better picture quality), so if anyone has suggestions I'd love to hear them.

So probably doesn't exist as a web app that I could customize? I would need to program it myself?
If so, what language would be good to use? I'm willing to learn it but wouldn't know what would be suited to the purpose. You said "script" so I was thinking Javascript.

That should work as you expect it, the TV should(might need to adjust a setting) just pass the audio through the optical cable to your reeceiver. The only difference is your TV will perform the input switching instead of the receiver.

If you where using a timer, wouldn't the problem be reversed? The first toast will be less done since the heating elements need to warm up. A timer seems like it would work well if it had some way to pre-heat the elements before the toast is added.
Just download ASTRO (or something similar).
Given that it only takes a few seconds for the elements to heat, it doesn't seem like that would have a significant impact on the end result.
Until Apple's unfortunate hijacking of the word, what you describe is precisely what has been called a "Tablet PC" for a number of years.

Hmm. That makes sense - in order to send richer data, they need to use up more. "A", "B", "C", and "D" probably refer to huge (and possibly overlapping) ranges of channels that correspond to 1-11 on my router. I'll look into the 5.8 GHz, but then I would have to worry about interference on the 5.8 GHz phones in the house as well.
Yes indeed. There's another frequency that phones can use (900 Mhz I believe for DECT), but you've only really got 3 bands so Wifi, TV and phone tend to trip over each other.

Well, I'm digging around now. I decided to buy new phones from newegg at 1.9 GHz (DECT) and am looking for a TV sender at 5.8 GHz. If I can split the three types of communication up, I should be good.

There is no single answer to this question. Poll questions are typically Community Wiki by convention. It would also be a more useful question if answers include why the particular ROM was chosen, e.g. what features it has that set it apart.

I find it hard to use compared to Transdroid wich is much more adapted to small screen.

you can use the cursor on the Wii to move between items then click, it's not the greatest experience but it does work.
I like the Logitech Harmony remotes as well. I still have an old Harmony 880 that I use. The adapter will be the way to go for the PS3. Fortunately, the XBox 360 doesn't need one.
That is so cool! I CANNOT believe these are for real!
That's great! The DayDeal web site has also a bunch of stylus and other goodies.

Unfortunately my laptop is circa 2002. It doesn't have enought ram or horsepower for HD content. It only has a D-Sub 15 and the onboard graphics tops out at 1280x800. Used to be 2GB limit, but new OS's and hardware boost the supported values. Have an 8GB in mine right now.
Phone still fits best for me. Alarm clock has not only smartphones.

@BillN - yes, that's how all Harmony remotes work. The various models differ in # of modes, # of devices (even the low end ones support like 10 devices), and # of mode hard-keys. For instance, the 620 has 3 mode hard keys and a 'other modes' hardkey, while some units don't have any hardkeys and just use the display keys to select mode.
Thanks, but doesn't look very travel friendly.
I love our Harmony remote. It's got a ton of room for user-configurable macros. For example, we have "PS2 + iPod", if I want to play the Playstation 2 but listen to a podcast. :)
Do you have to use the B&N reader (on other platforms) to read books purchased from B&N, or are they readable on other devices, like the Sony e-reader?

For B&N books you have to use the reader, for the other filetypes there are several options for each platform (PC, iPhone, etc.). But again, you can use Fictionwise or other sources, and never actually use the B&N store to get books.

If you're planning to learn about mobile Windows development on 6.5 so that you'll be ready for 7, you're out-of-luck. Apps developed on 6.5 won't be compatible with 7, and 6.5 has a very dim future. I recommend skipping 6.5 unless you have a very secure market (like a large company that is totally committed to 6.5.)

@Michael Kohne: I believe syncing to Outlook should be possible. The problem seems to be, that we no longer own a windows machine .. so there is no outlook etc. I guess that is the downside of going Mac/Linux only.

As it stands many of the answers to this question are of little to no value. If you are going to add an answer please follow @Ivo's suggestion and include some supporting information to make the answers useful.
+1 for suggesting iPad/iPhone. I have iBooks installed on my iPod touch. I have not read very much yet, but I have not seen any flicker or flashing while turning pages. Looks very smart.
Yeah it's just the nature of the beast. It's not too bad though, after a while you don't really notice it anymore.
@geoffc if a question is a duplicate you can flag it for moderator attention and indicate the id of the duplicate.

This is generally a bad idea, IMO. While many electronic circuits may have some sort of voltage regulation module (VRM) on them, you can't really depend on it being there. As Tooshel pointed out, +/- 10% is probably safe (and actually probably expected by the engineer who designed the electronic device), but more than that is probably not and you're likely to burn-out (or radically shorten the life of) the device.
it's a shame the selection at fictionwise is so narrow (at least for sci-fi and fantasy)

@lexu: do you have any kind of sync for the Nokia on the Mac? If you do, and you can export the contacts as a CSV file, you should be able to get them into Google Contacts. Similarly, Google Calendar takes csv files and iCal files - if you can get one of those, you're set.
While I think the iPad is a neat device, and has nice battery life for what it does, it is about 2 orders of magnitude off on battery life compared to many of the popular e-ink devices.

This site isn't for programming so I've closed this question. You may get an answer on http://stackoverflow.com

Thanks very much, this was helpful, I just wanted to develop this a a hobby, I have a thing for programming in different gadgets. and it will just be one off app for my convenience, I can send those myself but its nice to automate the process.. dumb ass. I am clearly asking where I can find some info on some device related issue, not about an error in my programming language. you guys need to lay off user's neck a little man, stack overflow closes my question saying its out of topic, and i come here to find the same welcome. whatever. Jeez! you guys!! piss on you.
@Rich Seller, the above comment was for you :-/

@iamserious your question is asking for tutorials on programming so I view it as off-topic for a gadgets site. You're of course entitled to your view, but please keep the insults to yourself. If you think development questions should be on-topic for this site, make your case as an answer to this question on the meta site: (http://meta.gadgets.stackexchange.com/questions/118). FWIW you may get some help on the Symbian forums (http://developer.symbian.org/forum/) or their wiki (http://developer.symbian.org/wiki/index.php/Developing_Applications_for_the_Nokia_N97)

@GAThrawn: Normally it takes about 2 hours to fully recharge. That's why I thought 10 hours is long.
Lots of people plug their phone in overnight to charge while they sleep, so I'd say 8 hours or so plugged in is entirely normal.

This is not actually true (it's a common myth that gets repeated a lot.) It really depends on the battery chemistry. Lead-acids operate best when kept fully charged. NiMHs and LiIons don't really care as long as they do NOT drop to full discharge. Partial discharge/charge cycles are much better for these batteries than full discharge/charge cycles. NiMHs are rated for 500 to 1000 FULL discharges, while it can easily hit over 10,000 PARTIAL discharges. The only advantage to doing a full-discharge is to allow the charge sensor to recalibrate itself to yield a better estimate of battery capacity.

Technically, your assertion that keeping a battery at full charge is correct (well, for Li-Ion battery anyway.) For long-term storage of Li-ion batteries, the quoted research is to charge it up to approx. 40% and then store it in a cool (but not freezing) place. This apparently is the best treatment for storing a Li-ion battery. But this discussion is not about long term storage of batteries.
The answer is only correct if the battery is NiCd.

what about services that say they only use HSPA (ie. wind mobile - see my list of service providers above)? I assume that's for both voice and data then? In this case, does it matter if my phone is gsm or cdma?

It only matters in the sense that HSPA cannot natively talk on CDMA or GSM networks without a radio in the phone for those technologies too. Which is why most all phones have only CDMA or one of the other ones. So you need to look at coverage in your area, places you would expect to travel to, and think about if you would be traveling internationally and then decide which technology best supports your needs. For me that would not be GSM or HSPA as their coverage in the Midwest of the USA sucks. Which is primarily where I travel and live.
You're best off asking the provider. They will be able to tell you. If you get clueless tech support, find someone with a phone on that service.

Both will let you change things based on time, location, plugged in, etc. I have my phone get quiet if it is plugged in, at home, and when I am usually asleep, a bit louder if I am at work, any time, and full loud the rest of the time.
